statement: Understanding Recurrent Ascites. Symptoms may include abdominal distension, discomfort, and shortness of breath.
matched_evidence:
- 2. Madhumita Premkumar,2025.pdf: Recurrent ascites refers to fluid accumulation in the abdomen that returns at least three times per year, despite dietary sodium restriction and diuretic treatment.
- 1.Chiejina M,2023.pdf: Patients typically report progressive abdominal distension that may be painless or associated with abdominal discomfort, weight gain, early satiety, shortness of breath, and dyspnea resulting from fluid accumulation and increased abdominal pressure.
page_location: Page 1, paragraph 1 | Page 2, section 'History and Physical'

statement: What Are Your Treatment Options?. Compare your options for managing recurrent ascites.
matched_evidence:
- 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: Management of patients with MA still represents a clinical challenge
for physicians. |Patients are highly symptomatic and require frequent
interventions, but standardized, evidence based treatment guidelines
are lacking. |The following paragraphs summarize existing data on treatment options for
MA. |A comprehensive graph on available treatment options is illustrated
in Fig. 3.
page_location: Page 4, Treatment options for malignant ascites

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Large volume paracentesis (LVP) involves insertion of a needle into the peritoneal cavity to drain excess fluid and provide temporary relief from recurrent ascites.
matched_evidence:
- 4.Aponte EM, 2019.pdf: Therapeutic paracentesis relieves the abdominal pain, distension, and respiratory compromise associated with large-volume ascites, significantly improving patient comfort and function.|Paracentesis is a procedure performed in patients with ascites, in which a needle is inserted into the peritoneal cavity to obtain or remove ascitic fluid.
- 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: The most commonly used procedure to relieve symptoms of MA is a paracentesis that provides temporary symptom relieve by draining the excess fluid.
page_location: Page 1, Page 2 | Page 7, under the section "Serial large volume paracentesis and permanent drainage"

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Outpatient procedure performed in a hospital
matched_evidence: - 5.Gilani N,2019.pdf: A retrospective analysis of patients undergoing an outpatient LVP at our institution was performed between January 2003 and May 2007.

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Repetitive procedure required whenever fluid builds up impairing QoL
matched_evidence: - 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: The most common palliative management for refractory ascites due to ESLD is large volume paracentesis (LVP), performed every 10–14 days [3].

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Up to 97 mins required per drainage
matched_evidence: - 7. Grabau 2004.pdf: The mean duration of large-volume paracentesis was 97 ± 24 minutes

statement: Diuretics. Diuretics are medications that increase excretion of sodium and water, aiming to achieve a negative sodium balance and reduce fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity.
matched_evidence: - 8.Zaccherini G,2021.pdf: The initiation of a diuretic therapy has the goal to induce natriuresis and consequently a negative sodium balance.

statement: Diuretics. Oral administration, especially for ascites from liver cirrhosis (requires careful assessment of kidney function, risk of hypovolemia, and ototoxicity)
matched_evidence: - 9.Arumugham VB,2023.pdf: Diuretics, along with salt restriction, are also recommended as the first-line therapy in ascites due to liver cirrhosis.[13]

statement: Diuretics. Administered once or twice daily
matched_evidence:
- 11.Magdy JS,2022.pdf: Furosemide (frusemide) is the most commonly used first-line therapy, which is typically started at a dose of 20-40 mg once daily in the outpatient setting.|To optimise the effect, it is recommended to divide the daily dose into morning and midday doses if more than 80 mg is required in a day.
- 10.Sica DA, 2011.pdf: All thiazide-type diuretics can be administered once daily, which for convenience sake usually occurs in the morning.
page_location: Page 2, Principles of diuretic therapy | Page 3, Refractory congestion and sequential nephron blockade | Page 6, under the section 'Clinical Usage'

statement: Diuretics. Regular monitoring required for electrolyte imbalance or kidney damage
matched_evidence:
- 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Prescribers must be cautious with it comes to dosing to achieve diuresis. |A black box warning states each loop diuretic is a potent diuretic and, at higher dosages, could lead to a profound diuresis with water and electrolyte depletion. |Careful medical supervision is necessary as adjustments to these drugs should be according to the patient's needs. |Electrolyte disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypochloremic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia, can lead to serious cardiac arrhythmias. |Electrolyte requires monitoring periodically to assess diuretic tolerance.
- 12.Aithal GP,2020.pdf: Diuretics can have side effects such dehydration, confusion, abnormal levels of sodium and potassium and kidney damage.|Therefore patients should be monitored while taking these tablets.
page_location: Page 3, section 'Monitoring' | Page 6, paragraph discussing diuretics

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. An indwelling peritoneal catheter is a long-term option for managing recurrent ascites, allowing patients to drain excess fluid at home. This supports greater independence and improved quality of life.
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|A key advantage of indwelling catheters is that they enable patients to remain in their own homes, potentially with support from home care services, rather than requiring institutionalization.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. One-time outpatient procedure to place catheter
matched_evidence: - 15.Tunneled Indwelling Catheters for Malignant Ascites ,2025.pdf: This is usually performed as an outpatient procedure by an Interventional Radiology clinician (2).

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Fewer hospitalization days improving QoL
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|Our findings demonstrate that indwelling pleural and peritoneal catheters are a safe and effective option for managing recurrent pleural effusions and ascites, with low infection rates, minimal hospital visits, and a substantial proportion of patients maintaining independent living.|By enabling home-based fluid drainage, catheters help reduce symptom burden without requiring frequent hospital visits, supporting both patient independence and caregiver well-being while also reducing hospital expenditures [16].|In our study, 70% of pleural catheter patients and 76% of peritoneal catheter patients had no hospital visits due to catheter-related issues.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Drainage performed at home
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].

statement: Frequency of Use. Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Repeated drainage at home as needed
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. |These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].

statement: Hospital Visits. Large Volume Paracentesis. Hospital/clinic visits each time fluid builds up
matched_evidence: - 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: The most common palliative management for refractory ascites due to ESLD is large volume paracentesis (LVP), performed every 10–14 days [3]. This involves a costly 24-48 h hospital admission, insertion of a temporary abdominal drain and removal of up to 15 L of ascitic fluid over 4-6 h.|Consequently, patients often delay the hospital visits until their ascites is tense and painful [8], thus reducing their quality of life (QOL) [2].|Participants randomised to LVP [3], the current standard of care, will be admitted to hospital as either a self-referral or via their GP, whichever is current local practice.
page_location: Page 3, Background | Page 10, Group 2 standard of care (LVP)

statement: Hospital Visits. Diuretics. Regular monitoring of electrolytes & kidney function
matched_evidence:
- 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: In those with advanced renal failure with symptoms of fluid overload, physicians should closely monitor fluid status and renal function to prevent the onset of oliguria, BUN, creatinine increases, and azotemia.|Electrolyte requires monitoring periodically to assess diuretic tolerance.|Clinicians should include periodic monitoring of blood pressures, fluid status (including weight), serum electrolytes, and renal function in continued diuretic treatments.
- 12.Aithal GP,2020.pdf: Diuretics can have side effects such dehydration, confusion, abnormal levels of sodium and potassium and kidney damage. |Therefore patients should be monitored while taking these tablets.

statement: Hospital Visits. Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Hospital visits not required once catheter in place
matched_evidence:

- 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: Importantly, 70% of IPC and 76% of IPeC patients had no hospital visits due to catheter-related complications, supporting the safety and outpatient feasibility of these devices.|Regarding hospital visits, 76% of patients had no catheter-related admissions, 18% had two visits, and 6% had three or more visits.

statement: Invasiveness. Large Volume Paracentesis. Minimally invasive bedside procedure
matched_evidence: - 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: The most common palliative management for refractory ascites due to ESLD is large volume paracentesis (LVP), performed every 10–14 days [3].|This involves a costly 24-48 h hospital admission, insertion of a temporary abdominal drain and removal of up to 15 L of ascitic fluid over 4-6 h.|In this feasibility randomised controlled trial (RCT) we will investigate the use of a simple and less invasive device, the long-term abdominal drain (LTAD), in patients with refractory ascites due to ESLD.

statement: Invasiveness. Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Minimally invasive insertion
matched_evidence: - 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: Despite the similar outcomes of open surgical versus laparoscopic techniques from randomized studies, the laparoscopic insertion has the major advantage of correct catheter positioning in the lower abdomen, with the possibility of adhesiolysis. | The minimal invasive percutaneous insertion bears the risk of bowel perforation and catheter malpositioning, and the outcome of this technique is strongly related to the experience of the surgeon.

statement: Pain or Side Effects. Diuretics. Electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, hypotension, ototoxicity, renal dysfunction
matched_evidence: - 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Adverse effects for loops diuretics typically occur from electrolyte imbalances secondary to the diuresis effects, which include: hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, hypomagnesemia, metabolic alkalosis, prerenal azotemia, dehydration, hypertriglyceridemia, hypercholesterolemia, hyperuricemia, gout, restlessness, headache, dizziness, vertigo, postural hypotension, and syncope. | Other adverse reactions include skin photosensitivity, interstitial nephritis, tinnitus, ototoxicity, deafness, and in patients with renal failure who receive high doses, myalgias, and muscle soreness.

statement: Pain or Side Effects. Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Infection and catheter blockage
matched_evidence: - 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: The outflow failure may be due to multiple causes, including clots or fibrin in the catheter, kink in the subcutaneous tunnel, placement of the catheter in the omentum, development of omental wrap or adhesions in the abdomen.|Obstructed catheters may be forcefully irrigated by saline or urokinase (Medicinase: 100 000 IU; 5 cc during 1 h).|Besides exit-site and subcutaneous tract infections, peritonitis is a feared complication responsible for 30% of the catheter failures.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Minimally invasive placement: A small tube is inserted through a tiny abdomen incision during a simple outpatient procedure.
matched_evidence:
- 17.Long term drains to treat ascites, 2024..pdf: Your doctor makes 2 small cuts in the skin of your abdomen. One cut where the wire is, the other is above it. | They pass the drain through the top cut, and under the skin to the wire. | They then thread the drain down the wire and into your abdomen. | When the drain is in, they remove the wire.
- 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: The minimal invasive percutaneous insertion bears the risk of bowel perforation and catheter malpositioning, and the outcome of this technique is strongly related to the experience of the surgeon.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Simple home drainage: When fluid builds up, connect the tube to a vacuum bottle. Each session takes 5-15 minutes.
matched_evidence: - 17.Long term drains to treat ascites, 2024..pdf: One end of the drain is in your abdomen. The other end is outside your body. When the fluid from your abdomen needs removing, you or your nurse connects a bottle to the end of the drain outside your body. The bottle has a vacuum that pulls the fluid into it.|It usually takes between 5 and 15 minutes to drain the fluid.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Continuous symptom control: Drain fluid at home, reducing hospital visits and improving comfort.
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|By enabling home-based fluid drainage, catheters help reduce symptom burden without requiring frequent hospital visits, supporting both patient independence and caregiver well-being while also reducing hospital expenditures [16].|Our study highlights their role in minimizing the need for hospital, maintaining patient autonomy, and minimizing complications.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 100% catheter placement success
matched_evidence: - 18.Proux A, 2024.pdf: Catheter placement success was 100%.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 76% had no hospital visits due to catheter-related complications.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 83% to 100% of patients enjoyed relief from ascites symptoms.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Infection rate as low as 6%.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. The catheter is inserted in the abdomen for draining ascites.
